text: Not a problem, @GaelVaroquaux. Together with @yarikoptic, during OHBM Hackathon, we have been working on enhancing the DueCredit itself and while at it, we decided to annotate some of nilearn's functions as a showcase :)
title: nan

text:
FWIW -- dependency on duecredit (if you check included in this PR `due.py`) is very very optional.  If there is no duecredit, all is good, no warning of any kind, etc.  Even if duecredit is installed, ATM you would need to explicitly enable duecredit mode (via DUECREDIT_ENABLE env var, or using `-m duecredit` option for interpreter) to get its machinery going.

But sure no problem, we could migrate those into the set of injections we maintain for such cases where upstream doesn't want to include them "properly".  In that case though it lives outside of the code base and there would be some cons (out of sync, etc)
title: nan

text:
ha -- see you there (well -- here).
As for social vs technical -- it is both.  In many cases users do not know what they should have cited.  E.g. do you always cite our NeuroDebian when you use it? ;-) (and I suspect that you do)
title: nan

text: Nailed it. The dtype of aal.maps is '>i2', so big endian. image._resample_one_img creates an output image of the same type, '>i2' for the output. But scipy.ndimage.affine_transform writes values in little endian, hence the mess.
title: nan

text:
Similar big endian problem appeared when using ```largest_connected_component``` from _utils.ndimage on AAL atlas.
```ValueError: Big-endian buffer not supported on little-endian compiler```

Basically, this will also have impact on this PR #1409
title: nan

text: With current master, we don't see any negative labels after resampling. @salma1601 Can you please confirm this one ?
title: nan

text: Yep ! No negative labels now, thanks !
title: nan

text:
You should be using like this:
Step 1: I am trying to create mask

```python
fmri_gm_norm = '/home/brain/Downloads/Audrey_Vanhaudenhuise/T1/mni_icbm152_gm_tal_nlin_sym_09a.nii'
T1 = '/home/brain/Downloads/Audrey_Vanhaudenhuise/T1/T1.nii'

from nilearn.input_data import NiftiMasker
masker = NiftiMasker(mask_strategy='epi',
mask_args=dict(upper_cutoff=.9, lower_cutoff=.4,
opening=False))
masker.fit(fmri_gm_norm)
```
Step 2: and apply it to a T1 image
```python
# You should `fit` your mask image first and then should be using to transform
# your T1.

data = masker.transform(T1) 
```

Hope this helps.
title: nan

text: Thanks a lot,  it works :)
title: nan

text: Sure ! Thx for pointing it. Can you make  a PR ?

text:
In Python, there are coding style rules (known as PEP8) that keyword arguments (here "cv", should not have spacing before or after the "=" sign. Would you mind removing those space, so that we keep the style consistent in the examples?

Cheers

text:
The documentation is reasonable, but data are not always reasonable...Could the code issue a warning rather than an error ?



Sent from my smartphone. Sorry for misspelling and brevity.

-------- Message d'origine --------
De : KamalakerDadi <notifications@github.com> 
Date : 24/06/2017  14:13  (GMT+01:00) 
À : nilearn/nilearn <nilearn@noreply.github.com> 
Cc : bthirion <bertrand.thirion@inria.fr>, Comment <comment@noreply.github.com> 
Objet : Re: [nilearn/nilearn] FIXUP: check invalid input for dim argument  (issue #1226) (#1474) 

@KamalakerDadi commented on this pull request.



In nilearn/plotting/img_plotting.py:
> @@ -383,6 +383,17 @@ def _load_anat(anat_img=MNI152TEMPLATE, dim='auto', black_bg='auto'):
             else:
                 black_bg = True
     if dim:
+        if dim != 'auto' and not isinstance(dim, numbers.Number):
+            raise ValueError(
+                "The input given for 'dim' needs to be "
+                "a float. "
+                "You provided dim=%s in %s" % (str(dim), type(dim)))
+        elif dim != 'auto' and dim not in range(-1, 1):

But, the documentation says range is in (-1, 1) ?

—
You are receiving this because you commented.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

text:
From the discussions and comments on this PR. To summarize, correct me if I am wrong. Fix would be:

-  To add in the documentation at related plotting functions saying "typically it should be in between -2 and 2".
- Raise an error or warning if dim is not 'auto' or not a number. I am more leaning towards raising an error.

title: nan

text: I also think that this `threshold` parameter is confusing for the user, something between 0 and 1 would maybe be easier to understand.
title: nan

text:
> I also think that this threshold parameter is confusing for the user,
> something between 0 and 1 would maybe be easier to understand.

But it cannot be between 0 and 1. The maps are not bound between zero and
one.
title: nan

text:
Then I guess we could rename it and call it active_ratio or something
similar. Right now the end user has probably no clue on why he should set
the threshold between zero and n_components.
Le 6 oct. 2015 4:47 PM, "Gael Varoquaux" notifications@github.com a
écrit :

> > I also think that this threshold parameter is confusing for the user,
> > something between 0 and 1 would maybe be easier to understand.
> 
> But it cannot be between 0 and 1. The maps are not bound between zero and
> one.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nilearn/nilearn/issues/721#issuecomment-145880114.
title: nan

text: I wish to work on this.How do I start?
title: nan

text:
We don't have documentation for contributing to nilearn unfortunately but you can check the [scikit-learn](http://scikit-learn.org/dev/developers/contributing.html#how-to-contribute) one. It has some relevant information about how to clone the nilearn repo on your local computer, run the tests, open a PR (Pull Request), etc ...

The basics is to try to understand the issue and open a PR with a tentative fix/solution which we can then discuss.
